text: In ancient Egypt, a stolist was a person who held the rank of priest and whom we understand to have been an adorner of divine images. At some time, stolists belonged to a group or guild known as nekrostolisteis, as is attested to by the archaeological finds of the Siwa Oasis, this particularly being an inscription dating to the 1st century CE.D. Frankfurter - Religion in Roman Egypt: Assimilation and Resistance (p.73) Princeton University Press 1998 (reprint), 314 pages, Mythos: the Princeton/Bollingen Series in World Mythology Series, [Retrieved 2015-06-29] ==References== Category:Ancient Egyptian funerary practices
title: Stolist
